moves.1. f4 d5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. e3: This is the K-side counterpart to the English opening. In that opening, White plays to control the light squares: in this one, White plays a dark-square game.
moves.3... Qd6: A little premature to bring out the Queen. 3...B-N5, pinning, is a better choice.
moves.4. Bb5: I take my own advice, and also make K-side castling possible.
moves.4... g6 5. d4: Another move to control the dark squares. I am eventually aiming to place a piece on K5.
moves.5... e6: Black, in turn, tries to take the light squares.
moves.6. Nbd2 Bg7 7. Nb3 Bd7: Black's development is nearly complete. The game begins to pick up in tempo here.
moves.8. Ne5: I plant my piece on K5, as planned.
moves.8... Bxe5: A tactical interlude comes here. If I immediately respond with 9 BPxB, Black can reply with 9...Q-N5ch winning the White KB. So I have to play BxN first, before retaking the Black B on K5.
moves.9. Bxc6 Bxc6: Now it is safe for me to capture the Black B.
moves.10... Qe7 11. O-O: I finally get around to castling... also taking the half-open KB file.
moves.11... Nh6: Black clears his back rank. He can now castle on either side.
moves.12. Bd2: I prepare to connect my Rooks with 13 Q-K2. But Black's 12th move makes me postpone this plan.
moves.12... f5: I'm not sure what the point of this move is. It lets me create a passed Pawn and puts me a Pawn up.
I naturally capture en passant, presumably forcing Black's Queen to retreat.
moves.13... Qxf6: Wow! A monumental oversight that ends the game instantly. Did he not see that the Pawn was guarded by the Rook on KB1?
moves.14. Rxf6: I seize the opportunity, and Black resigns.
